Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: SmartBot360: A Platform to Enable an Effective Chatbot Ecosystem
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be to enable smaller businesses to participate to the chatbot revolution, by making it easier to design and deploy chatbots. The initial focus of this project is healthcare, where there is great opportunity to improve the quality and availability of patient services. The key technological innovation is the facilitation of an ecosystem of chatbot designers and agents, through the creation of novel chatbot design, collaboration and deployment tools.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will create the technology to allow chatbot designers to incorporate human agents into the logical flow of chatbots. Currently, chatbots are designed in an ad-hoc trial-and-error manner, which is infeasible for small businesses who do not have the resources to constantly refine and evaluate their chatbots. The project will also create techniques to allow human agents to be productive when taking over chatbot sessions, and allow designers to improve the logical flow of chatbots based on usage data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chatbots are software programs that chat with users on chat platforms such as Facebook Messenger or SMS. Chatbots have become popular in the last couple of years, as part of the larger push towards AI technologies. The SBIR Phase I proposal’s main goal was to perform the research and development to facilitate the creation and continuous improvement of effective transactional (or goal-oriented) chatbot, where by “transactional” we mean that the bot has a goal such as reserving a medical transportation. The focus has been on healthcare applications.

The intellectual merit of this project includes building tools to allow non-technical experts to create and deploy powerful healthcare chatbots, identify chatbot inefﬁciencies and bottlenecks, and automatically suggest improvements to the chatbot logic. Further, techniques were developed to analyze chat logs and generate analytics to visually understand the effectiveness of the chatbots. SmartBot360 worked with many healthcare companies to learn the key functionality required for healthcare chatbots to be effective, such as privacy and follow-up capabilities.

The broader impacts of this project include the potential to cut the healthcare costs by automating routine interactions of patients with the healthcare system. Further, chatbots may increase the engagement of patients, which has been shown to lead to better outcomes are reduced costs.
